Description: A obo:IAO_0000115
Biological entity that is either an individual member of a biological species or constitutes the structural organization of an individual member of a biological species.
Material anatomical entity that has inherent 3D shape and is generated by coordinated expression of the organism's own genome

A system that has as its parts distinct anatomical structures interconnected by anatomical structures at a lower level of granularity. Multicellular, connected anatomical structure that has multiple organs as parts and whose parts work together to achieve some shared function
Synonyms: organ system, connected anatomical system, body system

Description: Anatomical structure that is an individual member of a species and consists of one cell or more
A region of the whole organism without well-defined compartmental boundaries

Anatomical entity that comprises the animal in the early stages of growth and differentiation that are characterized by cleavage, the laying down of fundamental tissues, and the formation of primitive organs and organ systems
Anatomical structure that is an individual member of a species and consists of more than one cell
Anatomical system that has as its parts the organs devoted to the ingestion, digestion, and assimilation of food and the discharge of residual wastes.
The gastrointestinal tract that is being formed during embryonic development starting with the formation of the primitive gut tube (or archenteron)
Organ system responsible for the food uptake and processing in the larva
Anatomical system that processes ingested substances in the adult
Anatomical system that has as its parts the organs concerned with reproduction, i.e. the male and female gonads.
Internal support structure of an animal composed of mineralized tissue. It gives shape, support and protection to the body.
The water vascular system is a hydraulic system used by sea urchins for locomotion, food and waste transportation, and respiration. The system is composed of canals connecting numerous tube feet.
The hemal system contains the blood. It is composed of a complex network of vessels mainly located around the gut.

ID URCH: URCH ? Since we will be adding a sea urchin specific description and since the UBERON reference does not encompass a description
Description: Anatomical region that corresponds to the upper half of the embryo, which later is composed of the mesomeres, and ultimately encompasses the presumptive ectoderm
Synonyms: animal half, upper half, upper hemisphere

ID URCH: URCH ? Since we will be adding a sea urchin specific description and since the UBERON reference does not encompass a description
Description: Anatomical region that corresponds to the lower half of the embryo, which later is composed of the macromeres and the micromeres, and ultimately encompasses the endoderm and mesoderm
Synonyms: vegetal half, lower half, lower hemisphere

Starts at stage: fully grown oocyte with centered germinal vesicle stage
Description: Cell component comprising the outermost layer of the animal region of the oocyte. It consists of a phospholipid bilayer and associated proteins
Pubmed id: Croce, J., Range, R., Wu, S.-Y., Miranda, E., Lhomond, G., Peng, J. C., Lepage, T. and McClay, D. R. (2011). Wnt6 activates endoderm in the sea urchin gene regulatory network. Dev. Camb. Engl. 138, 3297–3306.

Starts at stage: fully grown oocyte with centered germinal vesicle stage
Description: Cell component comprising the outermost layer of the vegetal region of the oocyte. It consists of a phospholipid bilayer and associated proteins

Starts at stage: fully grown oocyte with centered germinal vesicle stage
Description: The apical region of the animal hemisphere

Starts at stage: fully grown oocyte with centered germinal vesicle stage
Description: The apical most region of the vegetal hemisphere. Once cleavages have started the vegetal pole is characterized by the presence of the micromeres initially and then that of the small micromeres
Anatomical structure that has as its parts a maximally connected cell compartment surrounded by a plasma membrane
Anatomical structure that is part of a cell and that has a granularity level equal to that of a protein complex or higher.
Any of the organs or elements that are part of the digestive system

A membrane-bounded organelle of in which chromosomes are housed and replicated. In most cells, it contains all of the cell's chromosomes except the organellar chromosomes, and is the site of RNA synthesis and processing. In some specialized cell types, RNA metabolism or DNA replication may be absent

Ends at stage: fully grown oocyte with off-centered germinal vesicle stage
Description: The enlarged, fluid filled nucleus of a primary oocyte, the development of which is suspended in prophase I of the first meiotic division between embryohood and sexual maturity
Comments: This structure has been defined from another sea urchin species but is present in P. lividus as well

Starts at stage: fully grown oocyte with centered germinal vesicle stage
Description: The subequatorial accumulation of pigment granules (the so-called ‘pigment band’) in eggs or early stage embryos, which constitutes an unambiguous marker of animal-vegetal polarity
Pubmed id: Sardet, C. and Chang, P. (1985). A marker of animal-vegetal polarity in the egg of the sea urchin paracentrotus lividus. Exp. Cell Res. 160, 73–82.

Description: All of the contents of a cell excluding the plasma membrane and nucleus, but including other subcellular structures

Starts at stage: fully grown oocyte with off-centered germinal vesicle stage
fully grown oocyte with off-centered germinal vesicle stage
Ends at stage: fully grown oocyte with off-centered germinal vesicle stage

Description: A structure that lies outside the plasma membrane and surrounds the egg. The fertilization envelope forms from the vitelline membrane after fertilization as a result of cortical granule release

Starts at stage: fully grown oocyte with off-centered germinal vesicle stage
Ends at stage: fully grown oocyte with no nucleus stage
Description: A small cell formed by the meiotic division of an oocyte
The part of the late spermatid or spermatozoon that contains the nucleus and acrosome.
A microtubule-based flagellum (or cilium) that is part of a sperm, a mature male germ cell that develops from a spermatid
An organelle that develops over the anterior half of the head in the spermatozoa
The developing female gamete. A female germ cell that has entered meiosis.
A mature male germ cell
An undifferentiated cell produced by early cleavages of the fertilized egg (zygote)
Intermediate size blastomeres forming the animal hemisphere of the cleaving embryo
Larger blastomeres of the vegetal hemisphere of the cleaving embryo located below the equator
Small blastomeres of the vegetal hemisphere of the cleaving embryo located at to the vegetal pole
A progenitor cell of the nervous system that will develop into a neuron

Anatomical Structure: apical pole domain neuronal progenitor cell

Description: Group of four cells of equal size forming the animal hemisphere of an eight-cell stage embryo
Group of four cells of equal size forming the vegetal hemisphere of an eight-cell stage embryo
Primary germ layer that is the outer of the embryo's three germ layers and gives rise to epidermis and neural tissue.

Pubmed id: Li, E., Cui, M., Peter, I. S. and Davidson, E. H. (2014). Encoding regulatory state boundaries in the pregastrular oral ectoderm of the sea urchin embryo. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 111, E906-913.

Comments: This structure has been defined from another sea urchin species but is present in P. lividus as well

Pubmed id: gossellin and jangoux 1998 et Smith et al., 2008

Description: A simple dot of calcified structure from which a spicule will emerge.
Pubmed id: Heyland, A. and Hodin, J. (2014). A detailed staging scheme for late larval development in Strongylocentrotus purpuratus focused on readily-visible juvenile structures within the rudiment. BMC Developmental Biology 14, 22.

Description: A triradiate or hexaradiate minute calcareous skeletal element that initiates most if not all skeletal structures found within the sea urchin embryo, larva and adult.
Pubmed id: Heyland, A. and Hodin, J. (2014). A detailed staging scheme for late larval development in Strongylocentrotus purpuratus focused on readily-visible juvenile structures within the rudiment. BMC Developmental Biology 14, 22.

Description: The subset of the mesoderm that will give rise to the skeletal elements.
Skeletogenic mesenchyme is the tissue made up of loosely connected mesoderm cells. It is located in the blastocoel and will produce all of the skeletal elements.
Anatomical structure composed of skeletogenic mesenchyme cells that have fused to form a single syncytial network.
Subpopulation of skeletogenic mesenchyme forming a chain on the oral (i.e. ventral) side of the embryo.
Subpopulation of skeletogenic mesenchyme forming a chain on the aboral (i.e. dorsal) side of the embryo.
Subpopulation of skeletogenic mesenchyme forming a cluster (i.e. a group of cells) in the ventrolateral region of the embryo.
Subpopulation of skeletogenic mesenchyme forming a chain on either side of the developing digestive tract, along the blastocoel wall and towards the animal pole.

Anatomical Structure: right lateral chain of skeletogenic mesenchyme
Description: Subpopulation of skeletogenic mesenchyme forming a chain along the blastocoel wall towards the animal pole on the right side of the embryo.

Anatomical Structure: left lateral chain of skeletogenic mesenchyme
Description: Subpopulation of skeletogenic mesenchyme forming a chain along the blastocoel wall towards the animal pole on the left side of the embryo.
a cell that contains red coloring matter

Pubmed id: Ref pour structure tube digestif prism/plut: Annunziata, R., Perillo, M., Andrikou, C., Cole, A. G., Martinez, P. and Arnone, M. I. (2014). Pattern and process during sea urchin gut morphogenesis: The regulatory landscape. genesis 52, 251–268.
Vellutini, B. C. and Migotto, A. E. (2010). Embryonic, Larval, and Juvenile Development of the Sea Biscuit Clypeaster subdepressus (Echinodermata: Clypeasteroida). PLoS ONE 5.
Comments: This structure has been defined from another sea urchin species but is present in P. lividus as well

Pubmed id: Vellutini, B. C. and Migotto, A. E. (2010). Embryonic, Larval, and Juvenile Development of the Sea Biscuit Clypeaster subdepressus (Echinodermata: Clypeasteroida). PLoS ONE 5. Chino et al., 1994  Formery et al., (in prep.) Smith et al., 2008
Comments: This structure has been defined from another sea urchin species but is present in P. lividus as well

Description: Opening located in the left lateral field
The lateral field is located in the aboral ectoderm of the larva. It separates the anterior and posterior pairs of epaulettes
The left lateral field is the lateral field located on the left side of the larva
The right lateral field is the lateral field located on the right side of the larva
